div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: LEVANT POLITICS
div.p: Amid the contradictory reports referring both to the illness of H.I.M. the Sultan and to the question of the succession to the Ottoman throne, one fact stands out pre-eminently: [COLUMN BREAK] the imminence of a diplomatic struggle be-tween Germany and Great Britain for the first place in the regard of the Ruler of the one great Moslem State. In the preliminary bouts Germany has undoubtedly been successful. It remains to be seen whether the per-sonal influence to the Kaiser will be equally potent with the next Sultan and Khalif as it has been with Sultan Abdul Hamid II. The question is one of the greatest difficulty, and our diplomatists will need to walk with the utmost circumspection, stepping cautiously, per ignes suppositos cinero dolopso. [PARAGRAPH BREAK] A false step may be productive of the ut-most danger to the British Empire, and our opponents will do their utmost- and rightly, too, from their point of view—to lead us into some pitfall from which we shall emerge in very sorry plight. To guard against this danger we require not only diplomatists and consuls, men of political discernment and special local knowledge, in the Levant, but statesmen at home who are something more than the mouthpieces of a party or the con-ciliators of a discordant Cabinet. To the vigour with which it has almost always seconded a “spirited” foreign policy the British public has seldom united the minimum of discretion, and its love of the sentimental, its occasional flirtations with the impracticable, and its mar-vellous readiness to believe all that it hears, make it a peculiarly dangerous creature—to itself. [PARAGRAPH BREAK] A few years ago the pro-Armenian campaign was in full swing. There was much to be said on behalf of the Armenians, and their punishment, attended as it was by revolting barbarities, was altogether out of proportion to the offence. But we cannot help thinking that had the public, instead of calling for war and the creation of an independent Armenia, urged, nay, commanded the Government not to rest till it had brought about the adoption of a respectable police organization in Kurdistan, we should have won the gratitude not only of the Armenians, but of the vast majority of decent Moslems who dislike being robbed by Kurds and Circassians as much as Christians, and we should not have fallen between two stools. Had we gone to war we should have run some risks, but should at least have won the respect of the Turk, of the Eastern Christians, and of some of the Great Powers. As it was, we exasperated Turkish sentiment and gave the Kaiser his chance. We sympathized vastly with the Armenians, and we failed to afford them any assistance—a few sonnets by Mr. William Watson and some charity bazaars excepted. [PARAGRAPH BREAK] The Armenian troubles over, we sympathized most enthusiastically with the Greeks,--the upholders of civilization against the barbarous Turk. After the Greek Army had sustained a series of lamentable disasters, which culminated in the catastrophe of the Furka Pass, we realized that we had gone rather too far. The exploits of the Greek bands and of Bulgaria komitajis in Macedonia caused some of the loudest denouncers of Moslem intolerance to wonder whether the “unspeakable” Turk, of whom they had constantly spoken, really had the monopoly of outrages in the Balkans. Then came the stirring of Pan-Islam=ism and the discovery that the Ottoman Government was not actuated by the friendliest sentiments to the British Empire. [PARAGRAPH BREAK] There was another school among us. To its followers the Turk was a marvel of intelligence, the possessor of every Moslem and Christian virtue. True he was a little rough at times, but wild, manly races were a trifle rough when they dealt with rebels. They said of the Turkish Empire “Preserve it”—their opponents, “End it” but as yet no middle school has arisen (we refer not to statesmen, of the publicists but to the average man) that will have the courage to say—“Help to mend it.”Amid the contradictory reports referring both to the illness of H.I.M. the Sultan and to the question of the succession to the Ottoman throne, one fact stands out pre-eminently: [COLUMN BREAK] the imminence of a diplomatic struggle be-tween Germany and Great Britain for the first place in the regard of the Ruler of the one great Moslem State. The question is one of the greatest difficulty, and our diplomatists will need to walk with the utmost circumspection, stepping cautiously, per ignes suppositos cinero dolopso.

A false step may be productive of the ut-most danger to the British Empire, and our opponents will do their utmost- and rightly, too, from their point of view—to lead us into some pitfall from which we shall emerge in very sorry plight. To guard against this danger we require not only diplomatists and consuls, men of political discernment and special local knowledge, in the Levant, but statesmen at home who are something more than the mouthpieces of a party or the con-ciliators of a discordant Cabinet. To the vigour with which it has almost always seconded a “spirited” foreign policy the British public has seldom united the minimum of discretion, and its love of the sentimental, its occasional flirtations with the impracticable, and its mar-vellous readiness to believe all that it hears, make it a peculiarly dangerous creature—to itself. [PARAGRAPH BREAK] A few years ago the pro-Armenian campaign was in full swing. There was much to be said on behalf of the Armenians, and their punishment, attended as it was by revolting barbarities, was altogether out of proportion to the offence. Had we gone to war we should have run some risks, but should at least have won the respect of the Turk, of the Eastern Christians, and of some of the Great Powers. As it was, we exasperated Turkish sentiment and gave the Kaiser his chance. We sympathized vastly with the Armenians, and we failed to afford them any assistance—a few sonnets by Mr. William Watson and some charity bazaars excepted. [PARAGRAPH BREAK] The Armenian troubles over, we sympathized most enthusiastically with the Greeks,--the upholders of civilization against the barbarous Turk. div.head: Church of Scotland.
div.p: There will be a New Year’s Servioe at Saint Andrew’s Churoh (off Kasr-el Nil-street, Cairo) at 10.30 a.m. to-morrow. The Rev. J. A. McClymont, D.D., will officiate.

Soldiers and Sailors’ Institute. A donation of £3 has been received, through Mrs. Kingham, from Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, the Governor of Alexandria, in lieu of purchases at the Fancy Sale on the 19th inst. Cairo Rifle Meeting. The annual Army and Navy Rifle Meeting will take place on the Abbassieh ranges on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, February, 26th, 27th, 28th and March 1st next. Egyptian University. Khalil Bey El Diwani, Hassan Eff Hassan El-Rafi, of Dessouk, and Mr. Max Fischer have subscribed L E. 250, L.E. 100, and L.E. 10, respectively, to the funds of the proposed University. State Railway Institute. The annnal children’s festival will be held at the Institute on New Year's Day. The pro-gramme is as follows : 2 p.m, sports ; 5 p.m., tea ; 6 p.m., cinematograph ; 8 p.m., concert ; 10 p.m., dance. Bread for Schools. The oontraot for the supply of bread during 1907 for the kuttubs of the Publio Works Ministry has been obtained by Youssef Aly Gadalleph, who tendared at 11 milliemes the oke (8. 8 mill, per kilogramme). New Mosque for Calloub. Shawarbi Pasha, who not long ago establish-ed a hospital at Galioub, has now erected a mosque in the same village, which was in-augurated on Friday, when a large number of native notables attended Friday prayer at the new mosque.

Coal Imports. For the year up to December 27 the imports of coal at Alexandria totalled 1,238 966 tons, made up as follows : Welsh, 673 516 ; New-castle, 208,833 ; Scotch, 115,841 ; Yorkshire, 179,270 ; other qualities, 61,516. The total for the same period last year was 1,042,783 tons. Mex Pumping 8tatlon. Four new boilers are required for Mex Pumping Station. The boilers are to be of the Galloway or Lancashire type 26 feet long fitted with a number of Galloway cone tubes, oonstraoted for a working stream pressure of 120 lbs. per sq. inch, and oapable of evaporating 5,500 lbs. of water per hour with average coal and draught.

American Mission. On the morning of the 28th inst. the graduating exeroises of the Amerioan Mission girls’ boarding sohool of Cairo were held and a lengthy programme of interest and merit was eojoyed by a large and appreciative audienoe. Lady Cromer was among those present The twelve girls who reoeived diplomas represent not only Cairo but Egypt northward to the sea and southward several hundred miles. Tbe Hon. Mr. Iddings, Consul- General for the U.3.A., addressed the class and presented the diplomas. Carage for Alexandria. Egyptian residents interested in motoring will be pleased to learn that the most popular and successful company, Humber Limited,have opened a repairing garage at Alexandria under expert English supervision, where all spare parts can be obtained and repairs executed at once. Tbe 10-12 H.P. 4 cylinder Humber is a British built oar throughout and every part is guaranteed. There can be no possible doubt that, in view of its low initial cost, inexpensive upkeep, reliability, and luxuriously smooth noiseless running, it is the most suitable oar for this country. Catalogues can be procured and free trial runs arranged for at the Bomber agenoy, 3 Rue Cleopatre. Alhambra Theatre. The company of youthful operatic artistes under the direction of Cav. Guerra still continue to draw good houses at this theatre, and the enthusiasm displayed by patrons has in no way abated. The season, however, is rapidly drawing to a close. To-night "Le Educande di Sorrento” will be staged, and to-morrow will be the last opportunity of witnessing these clever little people, when a serata d'addio will ba given in honour of Cav. E. Guerra. We can thoroughly recommend the performance as one deserving the patronage of all who appre¬ciate highly trained youthful voices in superior musical compositions. On Friday the stage will be occupied by “The Great Door-Leblano” who with his company gives an entertainment somewhat similar to that which has made Maskelyne and Cook so famous in London, and includes spiritualism, table turning, con-juring, thought transmission, and several Indian delusions. M. Door-Leblanc recently gave a very clever representation in theNew Khedivial Hotel

div.head: FLOODS AT SMYRNA
div.p: SULTAN’S MUNIFICENCE.

The Saltan has opened a subscription in aid of the sufferers by the floods at Smyrna, head-ing it with L.T. 2,00O. i Havas The entire valley of the classic Cayster has been flooded by an overflow. Villages have been washed away, lives have been lost, and property to the extent of L.T. 6,000 destroyed. Smyrna, according to the latest news, was under water and suffered considerably. Ghediz is the Turkish name for the Cayster, which flows through the valley next to the classic Meander.
EARTHQUAKE IN EGYPT.

Mr. Keeling writes as follows from the Observatory, Helouan As reported in your columns, a slight earth-quake was felt in various places in Egypt on the 26th inst. The shock was recorded at Helouan Observatory, and as it was probably of local origin it would be very interesting to know details of the occurrence. I should be very grateful if anyone who noticed it would send to me at the Observatory parti¬culars as to the exact time, and duration of the shook, and to what phenomena accom¬panied it (rooking of chairs, rattling of crockery, etc.).
THE ITALIAN PACKETS.

The crew of the Florio-Rubattino S.S. “Bos- foro” having been replaced, this vessel has been enabled to leave Brindisi on Saturday evening and will arrive at Alexandria to¬morrow afternoon. On 8nnday next the S.S. “Siracusa” is due at Alexandria, and will continue her voyage to Cyprus and Syria on the following Wednesday. This steamer is on her maiden trip, and was only launched at Palermo a few weeks ago.
THE POPE AND MENAS CITY.

Pope Pins X. has addressed through his Secretary of State a Latin letter to the Rev. Mr. Kaufmann, the Frankfort archaeologist. His Holiness expressed his sincere appreciation of the wonderful discoveries recently made by Messrs. Falls and Kaufmann at the site of the old city of Saint Menas in the Marions district. His Holiness is muc in¬terested in the excavation of this long-lost city, which was for centuries one of the most Renowned sanctuaries in Christian Egypt, and he desired that the two archeologists should know that they had his sincere good wishes in their magnificent work on behalf of Christian archeology and he hoped that the great¬ness of their discovery would be acknowledged by all the friends of that science.

POSTAL TAXES REDUCTION.

On and after to-morrow the Egyptian Postal Administration has decided that the following reduction of postal taxes are to take effect: — 4. The price of inland post cards will be reduced to 2 milliemes for single cards and 4 milliemes for reply paid oards. 2. The insurance fee on inland parcels will be reduced from 10 to 5 milliemes per unit of L.E.12 or fraction thereof of the insured value. The maximum for insurance is maintained at L.E 400.

div.head: EGYPT AND AMERICA.
div.p: ROCKEFELLER’S GIFT-

The multi-millionaire, John D. Rockefeller, has sent word to the officers of the Board of Foreign Missions of the United Presbyterian Church at Philadelphia that he would give $100,000 toward educational work in Egypt and the Sudan. The announcement was made at a meeting of the board, and a message of thanks sent to Mr. Rockefeller. Part of the Standard Oil magnate's money will go toward a college for young men and part toward a school for girls. It was nearly six months ago that the United Presbyterian Board wrote to Mr. Rockefeller, calling his attention to the rapidly increasing demands being made by the young men and women of the Nile Valley for education and western knowledge. Mr. Rockefeller took the letter abroad with him, and in the course of his trip took occasion to visit the two schools for which his aid had been asked. That he was favourably impressed by the work being done was shown by the receipt of this message. Rev. Dr. C. R. Watson, corresponding secretary for the board, said regarding the gift to the society : “Announcement was made to-day at the poard meeting of Mr. Rockefeller's gift of $100,000. The greater part of the gift will go toward the erection of new buildings for Assiut College.’’
DEATH OF AN ARABIC SCHOLAR.

We regret to announce the death of the distinguished Syrian scholar, Sheikh Ibrahim el-Yazigi, Editor of “Al Zia,”an Arabic liter¬ary magazine published in Cairo. The 8heikb, who died at Zeitoun, was the eon of a wall- known Syrian poet. The funeral took place on Saturday afternoon, the service being held at the Catholic Cathedral at Fagallab. The late Sheikh devoted a great part of bis life to improving the text of the authorised Arabic translation of the Bible used by the Oriental Catholics. He was also a great authority on Arabio calligraphy and did much to improve the Arabic characters used in print¬ing. At the time of his death he was engaged on an important Arabic lexicon.
THE CRUISE OF THE ARABIC.

All arrangements for the visit of the S.S, Arabic to Egypt have been completed. Mr. H. C. Clark, brother of Mr. Frank Clark, who has chartered the leviathan, has been in Cairo in connection with the oroise, and has gone to Rome to complete arrangements there. Book¬ings for the cruise have been excellent, every available berth being taken. The Arabic will arrive at Alexandria on March 13. There will be 630 tourists on board, of whom about 350 will go up river in different group by steamer and rail. The vessel will sail again for Naples on March 25.
HELLENIC CONSULAR COURT.

To-day began before Judge Papadopoulos, assisted by Counsel Dr. Lazaris and Livadaris, the trial of Psathopoulos, Sersphimide", and Messaris, who are accused of manufacturing false diplomas of the University of Athens. There was a grand jury of twelve, headed by Dr. Constantinos Tambakos. Counsel for defend-ants are Drs. Limbrites, Salamanos, Saltabassi and Katelnsos. The session lasted two hours and a-half, the Public Prosecutor being M. Yeleli, greffier of the Athens Criminal Court. The first- witness, by special request of Dr. Salamanos, was Mr. George Thomson, cotton merchant of Msn- sonra, whose evidence is most weighty against accused.
THE ALEXANDRIA SHOW.

A number of notables of Alexandria met yesterday at the Governorate to deal with the measures to be taken for opening the forth-coming agricultural show at Alexandria. Abd¬el Hamid Bey Abaza, who represented the Khedivial Agricultural Society, of which he is an Inspector, delivered a speech stating that having been authorized by that Society to call public attention to the benefits of a show being held at Alexandria, he would begin the work by asking the inhabitants to support the scheme. Abaza Bey was seconded by Hassabo Bey Mohamed, mechanical engineer, who also delivered a speech on the subject. A committee was formed to arrange for the show.

div.head: ABYSSINIA TO THE NILE.
div.p: THE PROPOSED RAILWAY.

With regard to the question of railway construction from Abyssinia towards the Nile, which, according to the recent Abyssinia agreement, is to be under British auspice?, it is to be noted that, according to the con¬cession of 1894, the right to construct railways from Adis Abeba to the Nile or to Kaffa belongs to the Ethiopian Railway Company, but there will be no difficulty in making the necessary arrangements for a subsidiary English company, if desirable, to build this section. ,
SAVOY HOTEL DANCE.

Every Saturday evening sees a larger as-sembly at the Savoy, and the season’s dances there are now in foil swing. There were the usual number of dinner parties in the restaurant last Saturday, Capt. and Lady Muriel Beckwith entertaining a party of eight; and Mrs. Saunders also having a party of the same number. Major and Mrs. Wynne also had guests, and BO had Lady David Tennant; and Captain H. A. Chandos Pole Gell and Dr. Wm. Armstrong both were acting hosts at bachelor tables. Colonel and Mrs. Churchward (nee Montgomery) who were last in Cairo some six years ago were also dining with their friends. Mrs. Collison, Baron von Vietinghoff, Major Walters, Captain Anderson, and Mr. Curphy were among the other hosts and hostesses. Dancing was kept up merrily to the music of the Ladies’ Orchestra till a late boor, and though there were various complaints as to the damage to pretty frocks caused by the spurs of the officers, no one allowed such minor troubles to discountenance them at the moment. There were the usual number of pretty toilettes to be seen, and certainly none were more becoming than those worn by the two beautiful Miss Andersons ; the elder of whom was in a lovely blank and white striped silk muslin and wore a huge Paradis in her coiffure, while the second was in blue with white lace underdress. Mrs. Blythe was also much admired in a wonderful dress of soft rose satin oriental with which she wore ornaments of coral, and Mrs. Wynne was looking quite her best, in spite of her accident, in a long trailing frock of some soft creamy material with silver emroideries on the corsage. Everyone Was glad to welcome back Mrs. Yorke and her pretty daughters who are looking fairer and prettier than ever, and the Misses Shaar also came in for their fair share of admiration. Mrs. Saunders was in a brilliant frock of soar let with a fashionable head dress of the same colour,and Mrs. Hooter was in yellow, though perhaps these two last-mentioned colours ought not to have been mentioned together. Mrs. Nolan was wearing a very pretty frock which suited her well, and Miss Moore was in white with a touch of bine on the corsage. Miss Joseph and Miss Fearon were dancing indefatigably as usual, and Miss de Codt, Miss Rees and Miss Johnston found many partners awaiting them. Mrs. Burdekins with Mrs. Hay and the remainder of her family were present, and M. Klobukowski, the French Diplomatic Agent, was also there with a party of friends, and naturally all those who were present during dinner spent the evening either in the dancing room or in the salons near at hand. A goodly proportion of the guests formed fresh parties for supper, one large table for fifteen being presided over by Messrs. Cuthbertson and Swan, and Major and Mrs. Wynne having a party of eight or so guests. Another dance at the Savoy has been arranged for New Year’s Day. The band of the Scottish Borderers will be in atten¬dance and doubtless there will be many officers from the various regiments present. There is a rumour that these Tuesday dances with military bands may be continued through¬out the season, and if they are so they will add immensely to the long list of its attractions.
THE NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL

We understand that the New Khedivial Hotel in Cairo is now under the sole management of Mr. J. Vocles, who for many years has been connected with hotel management in the hear East. The Hotel, which is quite new, and replete with every modern comfort and convenience, lift, etc., has already a long list of season visitors, and under the energetic and intelligent new management ought to be very successful and rank among the most comfortable family hotels of the Capital.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. City of Perth, of the Westcott and Laurence Line, left Malta on Saturday last, and is due here on Wednesday next, the 2nd proxo., with general cargo from Antwerp and London. The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Niger, from Marseille0, passed through the Straits of Messina on Saturday at 3 p.m., and is due here to-morrow

div.head: KHEDIVIAL THEATRE.
div.p: "CENDRILLON"

"Cendrillon" is a most harming and delicate opera, full of the most delicious phrases and effects and with plenty of humour. It is not of every kind of music that one can say that. M. Massenet evidently set himself to write a real fairy story, and he most have taken the keenest pleasure in it. The overture and the opening we missed, — so did most people. The honse was practically empty for that matter till about 9.15. My trouble, though, was not so much lateness as the animated discussions in the middle of the theatre. Alas ! all protests are useless. A discreet "sash" provokes laughter, and any touch of exasperation calls up blind fury in several languages ; and the raucous discussions arise again, Antoeus-like. Oh, that M. Escalais could be induced to proclaim nightly "il est defendu de parler affaires pen dant l’Opera” or some such phrases. He might end with oyez, oyez, oyez. The last ez in lit’ alt would be most effective. Bat pardon the digression ! I will only add that the baby in the gallery surely thought noise was the fashion, and strove to live up thereto. The opera opens—"Cendrillon" and her father,before the ball, and a most charming solo by M. Lorec, then followed by the entry and parade to a delightful 3 time trio by the Mother and two wicked sisters, who then go to the ball in all state. Enter then the fairy godmother and her chorus, these last in weird garb that looked as though it would not stand wear and tear : delight, transformation, and the sight of the long road winding up to the palace. Away to the dance, Cendrillon, and remember Midnight ! II Act : The tired prince, his courtiers, doctors and others, then five dances : these were very pretty. The mandoline, and les fiances were, to me, the best, but la Florentine seemed be tetter and more lively than most exhibitions of solo ballet-steps. The Rigodon du Roy was the grand parade of Cendrillon’s step mother and sisters. That and the appear ance of Cendrillon, now a princess, was quite enough for the guests who left her with Prince Charming. Oh ! la desolante aventure -one of the best bits in all the music, taken up in imitation by one after the other, and the chorus. Followed a duet, delightful and pathetic, then her flight 3rd Act: Again Cendrillon and then her father, and again a perfect duet, then re enter the family, disgusted, to the most fascinating heroic music,—Massenet laughing at their depit. Tableau,—the fairie's oak : the queen singing, (Mile Devilloy excelled in parity and sweetness of voice) and then the two lovers petitioning separately, then joined in a dream¬like duet. One perfect touch was the woven chorus on 4 ascending notes, repeated over and over again. Last Act: Cendrillon and her father on the terrace, she ill and he consoling. It was all a sad dream the fanfares below awaken her: delicious duet, and delicious fanfare and chorus below : but it was sorely a dream, for here are the family pretentions as ever,hunting the slipper. Cendrillon had "just invoked spring, delightful, consoling spring. But it ended in brazen fretful summer. Some ex¬cellent entr'acte mnsio—so excellent that my neighbours couldn't help hamming it, brought on the last scene of all. Love triumphant, and to one’s intense delight, the welcome of Cen¬drillon and her father, the 4-note chorus, and the ‘desolate aventure’ were the best inci¬dents where all was good. And all the per¬sonnel were good. Mile Karl as Cendrillon, far better than usual, Mile Devilloy delightful, M. Lorec as good as could be, and Mile Charpentier a most perfect Prince ; the mother and sister also noted and sang excellently. And then the chorus and orchestra were for once up to the mark : there were moments of tunelessness, but far more care and interest was shown all through. Besides, the more raucous of the audience vanished after the second act, and all the finale was paace and charming music undisturbed. Cendrillon is certainly a snores?, well worth hearing more than once.
ZIZINIA THEATRE.

We left the Zizinia Theatre in a lyrio mood on Saturday night, and to day abandon ourselves to the noble pleasure of praising, tor though we saw this piece twice at CoventGarden last summer, (with Caruso, as yet unadorned by his zoological hats, in his best voice), the Zizinia gave us an even perfection, not easily to be surpassed. "Tosca" is a melodrama written for three persons. These three welded each other together in such wise as to bring out and emphasise, by their infinitesimal deficiencies, each other’s strong points. Thus Scarpia's con¬summate rendering of his unlovely part drew our attention from the fact that his voice is deficient in strength and clearness, at the same time throwing into sharp relief the penetrating tones of Cavaradossi, whom, as an actor, we should be disinclined to praise. As for Tosca, she played and she sang throughout perfectly charmingly, entirely deliciously, and even in the first act, under the disadvantage of her monstrous hat, and hideous pink satin breast-collar (five inches broad against a willowgreen dress) she held the house between her fingers—in so much that we will not deny that the unbridled commandant had onr heartiest sympathy. We pardoned bis ill considered attempt ; it was his failure that we despised and deplored. For the rest, the Sacristau’s buffoon part is a ’bestialita," and nothing can be done with it. The orchestra got out of hand now and again in respect (or disrespect) of time, and again the prompter’s strident tones grated at critical momenta on our unwilling ears. But the evening was for ns a renascence, restoring and regilding those cynical years that had formed the unpalatable diet of the locust.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Francis of Bavaria, after a short excursion to Assouan, where he stayed at the Savoy Hotel, left on Friday by the P. S. May-flower for Luxor.
Sir William Willcooks, K.C.M.G., is leaving for Gondokoro from Khartoum on the 16th proxo.
Amongst the interesting people now staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, are Mr. and Mrs. J. Low Harriman from New York with whose party is Baron de Maroques from Paris.

Sir Benjamin Stone, M.P., is also staying there and was present at Saturday night's dance, as were also Mr. and Mme Cordonnier, who are so well known in Paris. Mr. and Mme Pilavachi with their son have arrived from Paris, and from the same capital also are the Count and Countess des Isnards, who arrived on Saturday.
The new Italian Ambassador, Commendatore Giulo Malmusi, is staying at the Savoy, and on Saturday WAS presented to the Khedive.

In spite of the injuries he received from his fall at the races last week, Mr. W. Horschitz has so far recovered that he has been able to leave the hospital, and return to his old quarters at the Savoy.
Mr. Douglas Morice, of the Customs Ad-ministration, is to be transferred from the 1st proxo to Cairo, to take up a high position in the Secretariat of the Finance Ministry under Chitty Bey,

Mr. J. de M Johnson, Sub-Inspector, Minis-try of the Interior, and Mr. Arthur Thomas Lloyd, Sub-Inspector Ministry of the Interior, having passed a satisfactory period of probation, are confirmed in their appointments.
Bimbashi R.S. Wilson, Junior Inspector of Kordofan Province, has been granted an extension of leave on a medioal medical until the 18th proxo.

The advance bookings at the Hotel d’Angle- terre are more numerous than ever, while the hotel is already much toiler than at the same time last year. Major General Sir John Ardagh and Susan, Countess of Malmesbury, are due on the 16th prox. Sir Richard Desmond has hooked rooms for the 9th, Lady Overend is expected to arrive on the 15th, as is also Dr. Waldo, Coroner for the City of London, and Mr. and Lady Norah Hodgson due early in February.

There is an exceptionally large number visi-tors in Luxor, which but proves that the healthy climate at that Upper Egypt town with its inte- restioghistorioalsnrronndings gets more popular year byyear. The Savoy Hotel maintains its old popularity and its guests are more numerous than ever. Among those staying at the hotel are Mrs. Lysons, Captain Lysons, Mr. L Lew- ragoff, Mr. V. Lewragoff, Mr. A. Lewragoff, Dr. and Mrs. S. Moeller, Mr. and Mrs. Ch. Wyllie, Mr. Armand Debetaz, Mr. St, John Diamond, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bailey, Dr. and Mrs. H. Laufer, Mr. W. Haepker, Mira Mabel Parmenter, Miss K'athelle Cracker, Mr. and Mrs. I. Bennett, Mr. C. L Freer, Mr. F. B. Mann, Prof. Dr. Miller, Rev. Dr. Colin and Mrs. Campbell, Mr. and Mrs. I. Meyoier, Mr. Henry Eles, Mr. and Mrs E. Blunter, Mr. and Mrs. B. Furlonger, Mr. and Mrs. H. Gilbert, Mr. W. A. Schmidt, Miss Annie I. Lawson, Miss Kellie McCallmer.

The first of the weekly small dances of Ghezireh Palace Hotel will be held on Wednesday, and for the rest of the season the dances will be held every Thursday. The music will be played by the band of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers. Among the visitors to Ghezireh are Mrs. York and her daughters, who were so much admired last season ; Miss K. de B. Carey and her cousin, Miss Fox, who is a daughter of the Hon. Mrs. Fox, sister to Lord Falkland ; Mrs. and Miss Crofton, who spent the whole of last season at Ghezireh ; Mrs. aud Miss Lumley- Cook. The Hon. Mrs. Lawrence is due wi,h a large party on January 9, as are also Mrs. Morcom and her son and daughter. Other visitors include Sir Hugh and Lady Smiley ; Mr. and Mrs. Frank Cook are due at the end of January ; and Sir Gilbert and Lady Parker, who were some time at Ghezireh Palace, have gone to Helouan.

Hotel, Port Said, are Capt. Robertson, Lieut. Rugg, Capt. Tardy, Mr. Menhaus, M. Mori Mr. and Mrs. Cecil, Miss Roberts, Miss Sat, Capt. Potts, Mr. and Mrs. Alford, Mr. Chotz-, Mr. MacDornald, Mrs. Dilberoglue FitzGerald, Miss Cross, Miss Ryan,’ Campbell, Mr. Topham, Mr. and Mrs Suter, Mr. T. Gould, Mrs. Carey and two daughters, Mr. Price, Mr. and the Mi York, Miss Myer, Mr. Munro Henry, Ruston, Mr. Tymino, Mrs. and Miss Wroome, Mr. Aiken, Mr. Long.
TERRIFIC BLIZZARD IN ENGLAND.
CATASTROPHE IN SNOW.

LONDON, December 29. A snowstorm has broken the telegraph lines throughout England. Trains are conveying cablegrams to the ports. A terrific blizzard is raging along the Scot-tish border. Practically no railway communi-cation exists North or South. Many deaths are reported from snow. The first local train since Thursday which left Arbroath late thia afternoon, packed with snowbound passengers, was standing in Elliott junction when an express dashed into the rear shattering two carriages and killing 13 and injuring 37 of the passengers. Mr. Black, M.P., for Banffsire, had both legs broken and amputated and lies in a most precarious condition. The accident is attributed to a signalling breakdown, caused by the snow.( R.) LONDON, December 30. Railway communication between England and Scotland is being resumed on all routes. Aberdeen, which was out off by rail and wire since Thursday, is still isolated. Three more deaths are reported from Arbroath, bringing the total up to 22. Mr. Black has succumbed. (Reuter
RAILWAY DISASTER. FOUR KILLED ; FIVE WOUNDED
BREMEN, December 30. The Hamburg Cologne express collided at Ostersberg with a goods train. Four postal employes were killed and five seriously injured (Havas)
RUSSIAN TALE OF HORRORS.
KAULBARS REMOVED.

ST. PETERSBURG, December 29. The terrorist leaders have revoked their previous decision to abstain from terrorism during the elections and have resolved to ceaselessly pursue the campaign. Two terrorists have assassinated the Gover¬nor of the Province of Akmolinsk in a Street of Minsk. General Kaulbars, Governor General of Odes¬sa, has been removed. This is attributed to bis connection with the "Union of the Russian People,” which is terrorising the city and assaulting Jews and students (Reuters)
CRISIS IN RUSSIAN POLAND
30,000 OUT OF WORK.

LODZ, December 29. Assassinations and conflicts are of daily occurrence. Fifteen people have been killed within three days. (Havas) LODZ, December 30. Six of the greatest cotton works here have been closed and 30,000 workmen discharged. The situation is most serious owing to the fierce conflicts between the revolutionaries and the workmen. Hitherto 12 persons have been killed and a score injured. The garrison has been reinforced. (Reuter)
RUSSIA AND JAPAN.
NORMAL NEGOTIATIONS.

ST. PETERSBURG, December 30. A Government communication has been issued here, dealing with the position of the Russo-Japanese commercial negotiations. It declares that although an agreement has not yet been reached on various contentious points, the course of the negotiations may be regarded as absolutely normal. (Reuter)
KUROPATKIN ON THE WAR.
DENOUNCES RED TAPE.
ST. PETERSBURG, December 30. General Kuropatkin’s book on the Rosso Japanese war, which has just been published, has been confiscated. He denounces the War Office methods. (Reuter)
MOROCCO.
END OF EL RAISULI’S REIGN.
NORMAL SITUATION.
TANGIER, December 29.

The Sultan’s letter was read in the mosques amid salutes of batteries. The situation is now almost normal. Guebbas’ troops have been fur¬ther reinforced. He refuses to negotiate with Raisuli, whom he treats as a rebel. The Sultan’s letter, removing Raisuli, describes him as a liar and a corrupt imposter, whose conduct is calculated to cause trouble with the Powers. It notifies his followers that that the Sultan is behind him to chastise him. {Reuter)
FRANCE.
PUBLIC WORSHIP LAW PASSED
PARIS, December 29.
The Senate has passed the Public Worship Law. The Parliamentary session is dosed. (H.)
SHIPPING DEADLOCK IN GERMANY. HAMBURG, December 30.

A serious shipping dispute has arisen here owing to the Hamburg-America Linie, the Deutsche Ost-Afrika Linie, the Kosmos and other companies requiring their officers to withdraw from the “Association of German Mercantile Captains and Offioers.” The majority have refused, consequently 8 have been dis¬missed and 71 punished. The officers resolutely demand the rehabilitation of their comrades. The companies are unyielding. (Reuter)
SHAH RALLIES.
PARLIAMENT GUARANTEED
TEHERAN, December 30. The Shah has rallied and signed the Consti¬ tution. The Crown Prince has also signed it, promising not to dissolve Parliament for two years. (Reuter)
MR. BRYCE
LONDON, December 30. The appointment of Mr Bryce, as British Ambassador at Washington, is officially announced. (Reuter)
FOOTBALL.
LONDON, December 29 The South Africans defeated Llanelly by 16 points to 3. (Reuter)
LORD KITCHENER AND MAHOMEDANS.

Lord Kitchener recently paid a visit the Mahomedan Anglo-Oriental College Aligarh, when an address was presented to him by the trustees of the institution, who, io thanking him for the interest he had taken in Mahomedan education, made special reference to the Gordon College at Khartum. His Excel lency, in reply, remarked that it was true he had taken the greatest interest in all questions connected with Mohamedan education, and he went on to say :— “It is only natural that I should do so, as for many years of my service I have been intimately associated with Mahomedans various parts of the world, and I am glad to say that I am privileged to number amongst my friends many of your co-religionists in Egypt, London, Turkey, and elsewhere. Since I have been in India I have had the good fortune to add to these numbers, as I have had the pleasure of meeting many Mahomedan gentle¬men, both in civil and military positions, who, I hope, will permit ms to call them amongst my friends. ‘It is very satisfactory to see that the education given here tends to increase the feelings of devotion and loyalty to. the King Emperor, and that spirit for military service which distinguished your forefathers in the past. As you are aware, a large proportion the Indian Army consisted of Mahomedan officers and men. These constitute some of the finest and bravest soldiers I have the honour to command, and worthily maintain the credit and reputation of the Mahomedan races of India.”

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN QUEEN.
div.p: HATASU AND HER TOMB.
Theodore AI. Davis' Excavations : The Tomb of Hatshopsitu. By Theodore M. Davis, Edouard Naville, and Howard Carter (Con-stable and Co.)

One of the first of the important finds made by Mr. Theodore Davis on the concession (the Valley of the Kings), on which he has been at work for the last three years. In the introduction, which forms his contribu¬tion to the book, he tells us how be and Mr. Carter came almost by chance upon a chamber which they had not time to clear, but which they felt certain had in some part of it a tunnel or descending corridor leading the veritable tomb. A literal toss-up decided them to make for the right-hand corner, where they found the tunnel they sought, and were led into the burial chamber containing the sarcophagus of the great queen. As it was empty, Mr. Davis gives excellent reasons for supposing that the priests in 900 B.C. removed the royal mummy to the hole known as the "cachette” at Deir el- Bahari. Here were found many other royal mommies, including that of the queen’s father Thothmes I. and two coffinless fe¬male bodies without wrappings. If Mr. Davis is right, one of these last must the mortal remains of Queen Hatasu: but it is just worth noticing that the Biban el-Moluk sepulchre was never finished, and that the blocks inscribed with the ‘Book of that which is in Hades,’ with which she evidently intended to line it, were found lying in confusion on the floor. It is therefore pos sible either that Hatasu changed her mind at the last and decided on being buried some where else, or that some palace revolution, doubtless headed by her terrible nephew and successor Thotmes III., led to her disrespect¬ful interment in some site yet undiscovered. The chief interest in this volume, however, is provided by a memoir by Prof. Naville, in which this sound and sterling scholar traces the life and monuments of the only woman who in the course 5,000 years ever ruled over united Egypt. Hatasu, Hatshepsut, or H4t- shopsitu, as the vagaries of Egyptian translitera tion have caused her to be successively called, was the daughter of Thothmes I. and Queen Aahmes. As she was of royal blood on both sides, she had claims to the throne superior to those of her half brother, also called Thothmes ; and as she must have early shown a capa city for sovereignty, she was during her father's lifetime associated with him on the throne, and brought up with the masculine name of Ka-ma-ra, or, as M Maspero prefers to read it, Makeri. Yet the Egyptians evi dently did not tike kindly to the idea a female sovereign, and Hatasu found expedient—as M. Naville thinks, while her father was alive—to marry her half- brother, who later reigned with her as her consort under the title of Thothmes II. On her husband's death, which, according to M. Naville, occured about the third year of his reign, Hatasu usurped the throne, though acknowledging the right of her nephew to succeed her husband. For some twenty years she thus reigned, calling herself king and not queen of Egypt, as she had done during her husband's lifetime. Yet she associated her nephew with her on the throne, as her father had done with herself; and when she died, he succeeded her and became the greatest conque¬ror that Egypt ever produced. M. Naville thinks that the relations of the aunt and the nephew were better than is generally supposed, and points out that the wholesale erasure of Hatasu’s name from the monuments did not take place until the close of the conqueror’s sole reign. But all the facts that can be verified about Hatasu are as here stated, and the recent attempt of the Barlin School to establish a series of dethronements and restorations, in the course of which Thothmes III. married his aunt and Thothmes II. allied himself with hi stillliving father and cast the pair off the throne, has been entirely knocked on the head by M. Legrain’s discovery at Karnak of many bas-reliefs showing Thothmes II. as king, with Hatasu, in the dependent position of queen, standing behind him. In other matters, too, M. Naville, with out travelling out of the record of ascer tained facts, gives us much-needed information He points out that Egypt at Hatasu’s accession was still suffering from the waste and ruin of the Hyksos invasion, and that it was probably due to her wise and peaceful rule that Thothmes III. found the land able to support the drain of blood and treasure imposed by his own Napoleonic policy. That she throughout strove with success to establish commercial relations with neighbouring nations is shown by her famous expedition to Punt, and M. Naville explains that much of the treasure which Egyptian kings were io the habit displaying on their monuments as tribute really consisted of foreign goods obtained by purchase or barter. He is also very instructive on the ceremonies attaching to Egyptian royalty, and shows from many examples taken from Hatasu’s monuments that the royal ka, or double, was worshipped during the life of its living counterpart, and that the many corona¬tion scenes where the Pharaoh is depicted as being crowned, baptized, and Installed on different throne? by various animal headed gods, represent ceremonies that were actually per¬formed, the parts of the deities being filled by masked priests, it is curious also to note that the cutting-out of a former king’s name from public monuments—a practice which has de¬scended to modern times—was thought really to lead to his annihilation in the under world, and that the fashion of walking backwards in the presence of royalty seems to be also derived from the ways of the priests in the sanctuary where the royal image was set up. In all these matters M. Naville's along study of the temples that he has for many years successfully excavated at Deir el-Babari makes bis conclusions especially valuable. The book makes a handsome pendant to “The Tomb of Thothmes IV.” from the same excavations, which forms part of the gigantic catalogue of the Cairo Museum.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to ell, to permit-within certain ueceeeary limit*- free discussion.
A QUESTION OF PRESCRIPTIONS.

To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.” Sir,—I beg through your columns to express the general dissatisfaction and disgust felt by the public in the provinces at the conduct of the doctors there, in whose ranks may be found also some European and some American doctors, who (to their shame or credit be it said, write our their prescriptions under special secret names, the composition of which is known only to them and their pharmacy that supplies “pure and reliable” (1) drugs,and which they consequently "petronite.” It is very apparent that their patients are naturally forced into the spider’s web, where, once entangled, relief and salvation can only ba secured by a further drain upon their pur¬ser. What the personal interest of the doctors in question is, remains a mystery, and likewise is only known to them and those they “patronise” Any of these mysterious hieroglyphics finding their way into other than the shops of the chosen few are “non est inventus" and the prescription is forced to go through the channel predestined for it. How the customer fares eventually rests between himself and his chemist and may be possibly discovered by our intelligent readers. These questions should be taken up and forcibly handled by the Sanitary Administra¬tion who have the power to protect the public against such examples of fraud and coercion from people they are naturally inclined to look up to as civilised and educated gantry. Kindly accept my best thanks.—Yours truly, A. H. Tantah, December 23 1906.
[ We do not believe that this is common—certainly not in Cairo ond Alexandria. Perhaps soma not very reputable doctors do this to get a percentage from the pharmacists ED. E G ]
THE PLASTER QUARRIES OF MARIOUT.
To THE EDITOR OF THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

Sir,—I beg to emend an erroneous state¬ment which has found its way through the columns of a leading French newspaper of our town, in connection with the gypsum-bearing deposits of the Mariout, recently bought by M. Emin Karam. Without going back to-dis¬tant antiquity, or referring to the first Bedouin who christened the place with the suggestive name of ouady el gyps, it is to M. Rend Four, of the Egyptian Institute, that we are indebted for any exact information about these deposits. In fact, in 1892, M. Fourtau, then engineer of the State Railways, brought before a meet¬ing of the “Institut Egyptien" the result of his geological observations in the Mariout We give herewith the conclusion of his valuable monograph : "L’industriel pent aussi tronver son profit dans le Mariout. Les carrieres de Ouady el-Gyps penvent fournir on platre an moins egal an plAtre de Paris. L'etendue des bancs de gypse est immense. J’ai constate leur existence sur one longueur ininterrompue de plus da 10 kilometres et je n'evalue pas la quantite a extraire a moins de 50,000,000 de tonnes !” And he added : “Pour redonner an Mariout son antique prosperite none n’avons qu'a faciliter les communications. Donnons lui les moyens des transports faciles et biento 'Egypte possedera une nouvelle source de richesse et de prosperite." i Eight years later, while on a geological reconnaissance in the Mariout, I was charged by two gentlemen, inspired from Fonrtan's memoir, to prospect the above gypsum deposits. Four sacks of specimens that I brought back were assayed by the engineer Koressios and showed to produce an excellent plaster. Two demands were only submitted to the head office of the moudirieh, but received no answer whatever. A month after a coastguards officer informed me that the Khedive took possession of the quarries. The concession of the Mariout gypsum has subsequently been given by His Highness to M. Syrigo, of our town.—I am, etc., D. E. PACHUNDAKI. Alexandria, December 29th.
A Chance for Ladies

M ADAME HALLE, the well known Con turiere, from London, is showing at the NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL (No. 24) a charming and varied selection of gowns. French model evening gowns. Smart afternoon dresses. English Tailor suits. Evening cloaks. A large number of dainty muslin and embroidered gowns. Blouses, petticoats, and corsets.
ALL AT Moderate PRICES.

div.head: On the Purchase of an Old Egyptian Mirror.
div.p: In Muhassib's shop I found it—there with kindred relics round it— Scrolls in hieroglyphics written, Scarabs, rings and jewels gay— And Muhassib said “My master, thees for ninety-five piastre” So I paid up like a Briton And I brought my prize away. Who were you of Egypt’s daughters, by some city of the waters - You who gazed into it often With frown or with a smile ? When it diagnosed a pimple or divulged a darling dimple, Did you sulk or did you soften, Dainty damsel of the Nile Yes, my fancy loves to paint you, with no tinge of vice to taint you, Yet with charming peccadilloes, As is woman's wont to day. Pleasure's cup was for your drinking ; still Ere you crept into your pillows; still each night when stars were winking, Yon could laugh or you could pray. Dark your looks—a fillet bound them, and the lotus bad that crowned them Served to gratify your passion For the realistic style. Yon were sweet on scents and washes—painted shoe?, bat not goloshes Painted eyes, too, were the fashion In the cities of the Nile. Ab, I've watched yon in the stately temple drop those eyes sedately, As yon listened to the chorus Sang by priests in rich array. Though at times your looks would wander to a head dress over yonder, And the hymn begun to Horns On your Tips would die away. Or at even to your chamber with your lyre I’ve seen you clamber, And you played it supple fingered Listless moments to beguile, And the notes would float and quiver till they reached the shining river- — There were spots where lovers lingered By the reedy banks of Nile. So my fancy loves to limn her—Egypt's child who in the glimmer the Past lived whole and human, Of With her minor for a friend— Lived to make in ancient ages slaves of kings and fools of sages : For woman aye was woman And she will be to the end. G.
LUXOR HOTEL, LUXOR, 20th December.

SKYE MEETING.

A Skye Meeting will be held at Ghezireh on Friday, 11th January, at 2.30 p.m. The entries will close at 7 p. m., on Saturday, to the Secretary at Ghezireh. Measuring day will be Saturday, 5th January, at 3 p.m. at Ghezireh. All horses and ponies not already registered, to be aged ; and those whose mea¬surements at 5 years old and upwards are not recorded in K. S. C. or A. S. C. Regis¬ters to be measured. The order of running will be the same as that in which the races are on this programme. There will be no lotteries.
FIRST RACE, 2.30 p.m.

THE MAIDEN PONY RACE. Value L.E. 40, 2nd horse to receive L.E 2 if six or more start out of the stakes. For Arab Ponies, weight for age and inches. Winners of L.E. 20 to carry 1 at extra, those of LB. 30 to carry 21 lbs. extra, and those of L.E. 40 to. carry 2 st. extra. Distance 1 Mile. Entrance P.T. 100.
SECOND RACE, 3 p.m.

THE NOVICES STAKES. Value LE. 30, 2nd horse to receive L.E. 3 if- four or more start, 3rd horse to receive LB. 2 if six or more start out of the stakes. For Arabs, who have □ever won a race of any description of value LE. 20. Weight for age. Distance 7 furlongs. Entrance P.T. 100.
THIRD RACE 3.30 p.m.

POLO SCURRY. Value L E. 15, 2nd horse to receive L.E. 3 if four or more start, 3rd horse LE. 2 if six or more start out of the stakes. For Arab, Argentine and Barb Polo Ponies, that have never won a race of any descrip¬tion including Polo Scurrys, 14 bands and under 12 stone, over 14 hands 12 st. 7 lbs. Distance 3 furlongs. Entrance P.T. 50. Only Ponies that arc bona fide Polo Ponies in the opinion of the Polo Committee are eligible for this race.
FOURTH RACE 4 p m.

THE NEW. YEAR HANDICAP HURDLE RACE. VALUE L.E. 35, 2nd horse to receive L.E. 3 if four or more start, 3rd horse to receive L.E 2 if six or more start out of the stakes. For Arab Distance 2 miles over 8 flights. Entrance P.T. 100.
FIFTH RACK 4.30 p.m.

THE MAIDEN HORSE RACE. Value L.E. 40, 2nd horse to receive L.K 3 if four or more start, 3rd horse to receive L.E. 2 if six or more start out of the stakes. For Arab-. Weight for age. Winners of L.E. 20 to carry 1 st extra, those of L.E. 30 to carry 21 lbs. extra, and these of L.E. 40 to carry 2 st. extra. Distance 1 mile, 1 furlong. Entrance P.T. 100.
SIXTH RACE, 5 p.m.

THE NEW YEAR HANDICAP. Value LB. 30, 2nd horse to receive L.E. 5 if four or more start, 3rd horse to receive L E. 2 if six or more start out of the stakes. For Arabs, the property of British Members of the K. S. C. Or A. S. C. Distance new half mile. Entrance P.T. 50.

div.p: The following business will be transacted at next Wednesday’s meeting of the Manioipal Commission : 1° Communications diverges. 2° Interpellation de Mr. Kamel Bey Tey moor sur la question de la route de la oorniohe. 3° Interpellation et proposition de Mr. Salvago sur l’6tat des routes, lear entretieD et l’enoombrement des trottoirg. 4* Question relative k une amende due par an fournisseur. 5° Avis du Comity da Contention? de l’Btat sar ane question relative aax notifications k faire aux Consulats, en oas de saisie adminis¬trative. 6° Demanded diverges de locations de ter¬rains des quais, prdsentdes par le Carole Khedivial, 1’Anglo Egyptian Hotel Co. Ltd., Mad. Silberberg, propridtaire du Palais de Crista! 7° Proposition relative aux exonerations de la taxe sur les voitores et bestiaux. 8° Proposition de Mr. Salvago tendant k l’admission de la presse aux stances de la Commission. Cirenlaire H. De Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES Le Cairo, 29 Deoembre 1906. Le taux de l’esoompte libre k Londres a 616 rdduit hier de 1/8 k 5 7/8 pour oent. Aa Stook Exchange le oonsolidd anglais est rest6 invarid k 86, l’Unifida k 102 1/4 et la National Bank & 28 8/4. L’Agrioole a perdu 1/8 k 9 5/*. La Daira a gagn4 1/4 k 17 3/4. La Delta L’ght s’est maintenue k 12. A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien est de- meur6 inohangd k 778, de mdme q~e la Banque d’Athknes k 138. Ioi la stance de oe matin a ktk plus on moins la reproduction de oelle d’hier, o’est k- dire un marohk de liquidation, k cette diffe¬rence prks que, la position se trouvant allkgke, la cldture a ktk relativement plus terms. Il y a, d’aillenrs, tout liea d’esperer qu’avec l’appoint des disponibilites qa’apportera l’kcbkanoe de fin d’annke, la. situation s’amkliorera dks 4e debut de 1907 ot que nous verrons se produire one reprise skriease. Dans le oompartiment des Banques, la Na tional s’est tassee k 28 1/4; L’Agrioole s’est maintenue k 9 5/8. La Cassa di Sconto a rkac tionnk k 282. Le Comptoir Financier a avarice k 8 3/16-1/4 et sa part k 98. La Bacque 1 d’Athknes a retrograde k 134. | Le Credit Foncier a molli k 779 et sa part k 930. La Beheraa progrease k 41 3/4. L’Enter- | prise and Development est revenue k 13 3/4; sa part e?t, par oontre, rem on tee k 21 1/2-3/4. | L’aotion Entreprises Immobilikres et deTra- ' ▼aux semble avoir subi qnelque pen la man-' raise bumeur des baissiers, qui ont fait nn nouvel effort poor oasser les oours. Nkanmoins le prix s’est bien main ten a k L. E 18. La part de fondateur a ete l’objet d’un fort moavement: de P. E. 138, prix de olOture d’hier, elle a haussk gradaellement k 161 poor finirk 158-160. L’Allotment a ete kohangk k 3 11/16-3/4 et sapart k 141->42. Les Jouissances Baux du Cairo ont fiechi k 278. La part de fondateur Automobiles avanos 110 9/16. ’ L’Bxpress Nile a ete traite entre 5 7/8 et 6 ' 1/8 pour oldturer aux abords de C ; sa part de fondateur a progressk k 108. La part Bourse Khkiiviale (1) da Cairo a ' ete enoore vainement offerte, sans trouver pre- • nears. On a parlk vaguement de £60; toojours est-il qu’il s’est present, parslfc il, an achetear skrieax pour deux parts k £ 10 pikoe. Il y a ane bonne demands en aotions Epar¬gne Immobilikre; mais il est difficile de trouver des vendeors. Toujours auoune operation en Ibrahimieh Ploughing malgrk toutes les concessions des ▼endears. Dans le groupe des valours hdtelikres, les Nungovioh ont ete ramenks k 21 7/8. Les Egyptian ^Hotels ont debate k 113/8 pour fikohir k 10 7/8. Parmi les petites valours, la Delta Land a ete mieax tenae k 4 5/8. L?s Ably se sont kgalement raffermis k 1 3/8-7/16, les New Egyptian a 32 sh., les Markets k 31 sh. et les Khedivial Mail k 40 sb. La part de fondateur Estates a gagne one livr^environ a 20 3/4 21 • * Nous reoevoos plusiears lettres par le.qiel- les on attire notre attention sur les oours de cldture fantaisistei ou plutdt tendanoieux qui illustrent le fameax tableau-bulletin de l’hono- rable Corporation des agents de ohange du Caire. Ces anomalies, dont les tenants et aboutis- sant sont oonnus, ne datent pas d’hier: le publio y est aoooututak de longue date. N’em- pdohe qa’elles dkpassent parfois toutes les bornes tolkrables, snrtout en oertaines cir- oonstanoes spkoialei. Et o’est le oas aujour- d’hui poor diverges valours. Hitous-nous toutefois de oonvenir que ces alterations ne trompent plus personne. Elies ne noisentqu’k leurs auteurs, en oesens du moins qu’elles aident simplement k rappeler l’urgenoe d’une regimentation serieuse de la Bourse. • • * La Bourse ktant fermke luddi 31 Decembre 1906 et mardi lar Janvier 1907 k l’oooasion des fetes da Nouvel An, le proohain No. de notre Ci roulaire ne paraltra qae mercredi pro chain 2 Janvier 1907. * • On .’attend i bref en Bourse, k une blame sur le? actions de l’Epargue Immobi- libre Ltd., qui sont en oe moment au-dessous du pair. Cette oroyanoe serait, paralt-il, bas6e sur la rumenr que la nouvelle Sooiete a dejk fait quelques operations qu’on pretend dtre trbs avantageuses. * S ♦ * L’aseembiee generate ordinaire de l’Alexan- dria-Ramleh Railway Go.,qai s’est tenue avant- hier b Alexandrie, a approuve les oomptes et bilan de l’exeroioe clo3 le 30 Soptembre 1906. Les benefices nets se sont eleves b L. E. 25, 571. Le dividende a ete fixe b 21 1/4 pour oent, soit 4 sh. 3 par aotion de £ 1 nominate. Uno somme de L. E. 4,000 a ete portee au fonds de renouvellement et L. E. 280 ont ete reportecs b nouveau. Carnet de l’actionnaire- On sait que le oqpseil d’administration de la Societe Agrioole et Indastrielle d’Egypte a decide remission de dix millions de francs d’obligations 5 0/0. Or, les actionaaires qui de- sireraient faire usage de leur droit de prefe renoe sont invites b s’adresser au sibge social au Caire on au bureau de la Sooiete b ^Anvers avant le 3 Janvier proohain.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907
